Testing random (or more=
 generally, non-deterministic) behavior is an
interesting question, and one=
 I like to ask during interviews.  We
could talk for hours about it, but I =
have a feeling you are looking
for a practical answer.

If you can seed the=
 random number generator (you probably should), you
can easily test the fol=
lowing:

- Two sequences with the same seed produce the same fortune cookie=
s in
the same order.

- Two sequences with different seeds produce differen=
t sequences of
fortune cookies.

You should also test for invariant propert=
ies (i.e. things that should
always happen or never happen). For example, r=
equest a fortune cookie
a large number of times and make sure that it alway=
s returns a "valid"
string.  You can define a valid string as a non-null, n=
on-empty string
or, even better, every string you return should be in the s=
et of
fortune cookies strings you are using.  The latter implies that the
s=
et of fortune cookies strings should not include null or empty
strings - wh=
ich sounds like a good property of a fortune cookie
generator (unless you h=
ave a nihilistic view of life) and something
else that you should test.

Th=
ere are many other very interesting techniques for testing
randomness, but =
I think they might be overkill for a fortune cookie
generator. But if you a=
re interested in learning more about this type
of testing, I wrote a chapte=
r on testing for the O'Reilly book
"Beautiful Code" which covers some of th=
ese ideas. Here's a link to it:

http://junitfactory.com/articles/beautiful=
-code/BeautifulTests.pdf

I hope this helps,
